symptoms: Olive-green to brown lesions on leaves, fruit, and twigs
Lesions may appear velvety and may have yellow or brown margins
Severe infections can cause defoliation, fruit drop, and reduced yield
Secondary infections may occur, leading to cankers and dieback
causes: Fungal infection by Venturia inaequalis
Favors moist conditions (high humidity, frequent rain, dew)
Overwinters on fallen leaves and fruit
treatments: Apply fungicides preventively, starting at bud break
Remove and destroy fallen leaves and fruit to reduce overwintering inoculum
Prune and destroy infected twigs and branches
prevention: Plant resistant apple varieties
Remove and destroy fallen leaves and fruit
Practice good orchard sanitation
Maintain good air circulation and reduce humidity
Apply fungicides preventively in areas with a history of apple scab

symptoms: Circular or irregular-shaped, sunken cankers on fruit, twigs, and branches
Cankers may have a raised margin and a dark, cracked center
Infected fruit may become mummified and shriveled
Severe infections can cause defoliation, dieback, and reduced yield
causes: Fungal infection by Botryosphaeria obtusa
Favors warm, humid weather and wounds on the tree
Overwinters on infected plant material
treatments: Prune and destroy infected twigs and branches
Apply fungicides preventively, starting at early fruit development
Ensure proper tree nutrition and irrigation to reduce tree stress
prevention: Plant resistant apple varieties
Prune and destroy infected twigs and branches
Practice good orchard sanitation
Reduce tree stress through proper nutrition and irrigation
Apply fungicides preventively in areas with a history of apple blackrot

symptoms: Bright orange or yellow spots on leaves, fruit, and twigs
Spots may have a reddish-brown ring around them
Severe infections can cause defoliation, dieback, and reduced yield
causes: Fungal infection by Gymnosporangium juniperi-virginianae
Requires both an apple or crabapple tree and a nearby juniper or cedar tree to complete its life cycle
Favors cool, wet weather in the spring
treatments: Apply fungicides preventively, starting at bud break
Remove nearby juniper or cedar trees if possible
Prune and destroy infected twigs and branches
prevention: Plant resistant apple varieties
Remove nearby juniper or cedar trees if possible
Practice good orchard sanitation
Ensure proper air circulation and reduce humidity
Apply fungicides preventively in areas with a history of cedar apple rust

Infected fruit may be misshapen, stunted, or cracked
Severe infections can lead to reduced yield and fruit quality
causes: Fungal infection by Podosphaera clandestina
Favors warm, dry weather with high humidity at night
Overwinters on infected plant debris and buds
treatments: Apply fungicides preventively, starting at bud break
Ensure proper tree nutrition and irrigation to reduce tree stress
Remove and destroy infected plant debris

Practice good orchard sanitation
Ensure proper air circulation and reduce humidity
Avoid overhead irrigation

symptoms: Circular, sunken lesions on fruit, leaves, and stems
Lesions may have a black, sunken center and a reddish-brown margin
Infected fruit may shrivel and turn black
Severe infections can lead to defoliation and reduced yield
causes: Fungal infection by Guignardia bidwellii
Favors warm, wet weather during the growing season
Overwinters on infected plant debris and can survive in dormant buds
treatments: Apply fungicides preventively, starting at bud break
Ensure proper vineyard sanitation, including removal and destruction of infected plant debris
Prune and destroy infected canes and clusters
prevention: Plant resistant grape varieties
Ensure proper air circulation and reduce humidity
Avoid overhead irrigation

Grape_Esca.scientific_name: Phaeomoniella chlamydospora, Phaeoacremonium aleophilum, Fomitiporia mediterranea
symptoms: Yellowing and necrosis of leaves, often along the veins
Reddish-brown discoloration in the wood of young shoots and cordons
Black discoloration in the wood of older trunks
Small black spots on the leaves, often with a yellow halo
Premature leaf drop
Stunted growth and reduced yield
causes: Infection by multiple fungi, including Phaeomoniella chlamydospora, Phaeoacremonium aleophilum, and Fomitiporia mediterranea
Spread by pruning wounds, insect damage, and grafting
Favored by warm, dry weather and poor nutrition
treatments: Prune infected wood and dispose of it away from the vineyard
Apply fungicides according to label directions
Improve vine nutrition through fertilization and soil management
Use insecticides to control insect vectors, such as the grapevine moth
prevention: Use certified disease-free planting material
Avoid pruning during rainy weather
Disinfect pruning tools between cuts with 70% ethanol or 10% bleach solution
Promote healthy vine growth through proper nutrition and irrigation
Maintain proper canopy management practices, such as shoot thinning and leaf removal
Avoid wounding vines and minimize insect damage
Apply fungicides preventatively before symptoms appear, according to label directions

symptoms: Irregularly shaped brown or reddish-brown lesions on leaves, which may be surrounded by a yellow halo
Lesions may coalesce and cause defoliation
Small black fruiting bodies may be visible on lesions
causes: Infection by the fungus Phomopsis viticola
Favored by warm, wet weather and prolonged leaf wetness
Spread by spores from infected plant material or nearby infected plants
treatments: Prune infected plant material and dispose of it away from the vineyard
Apply fungicides according to label directions
Improve air circulation and reduce humidity by spacing vines adequately and using trellises
Maintain proper canopy management practices, such as shoot thinning and leaf removal
prevention: Select disease-resistant grape varieties when possible
Prune vines regularly to promote air circulation and reduce humidity
Use proper canopy management practices, such as shoot thinning and leaf removal
Avoid overhead irrigation, which can promote leaf wetness
Apply fungicides preventatively before symptoms appear, according to label directions

symptoms: Small, round to oval, reddish-brown to black pustules on leaves, husks, and stalks
Yellow to pale-green chlorotic streaks may appear on the leaves surrounding the pustules
Severe infections can lead to premature death of leaves, stunted growth, and reduced yield
causes: Fungal infection by Puccinia sorghi
Favors warm temperatures (60-80Â°F) and high humidity
Spreads rapidly in fields with high nitrogen levels
treatments: Plant Maize varieties with genetic resistance to common rust
Rotate Maize crops with non-host crops
Apply fungicides preventively, starting at early vegetative growth stages
prevention: Plant resistant Maize varieties
Avoid planting Maize in fields with a history of common rust
Practice crop rotation
Reduce nitrogen levels in the soil
Maintain good plant nutrition and irrigation practices

symptoms: Long, cigar-shaped lesions with gray-green centers and brown borders on leaves
Lesions may coalesce, causing large areas of necrosis
Severe infections can lead to premature death of leaves, reduced yield, and increased susceptibility to other diseases
causes: Fungal infection by Exserohilum turcicum
Favors warm temperatures (72-86Â°F) and high humidity
Spreads rapidly in fields with high nitrogen levels and dense plant populations
treatments: Plant maize varieties with genetic resistance to northern leaf blight
Rotate maize crops with non-host crops
Apply fungicides preventively, starting at early vegetative growth stages
prevention: Plant resistant maize varieties
Avoid planting maize in fields with a history of northern leaf blight
Practice crop rotation
Reduce nitrogen levels in the soil
Maintain good plant nutrition and irrigation practices

Maize_Cercospora_Leaf_Spot.disease: Maize Cercospora Leaf Spot (Gray Leaf Spot)
symptoms: Small, circular to oval, grayish-white lesions with dark margins on leaves
Lesions may coalesce, causing large areas of necrosis
Severe infections can lead to premature death of leaves, reduced yield, and increased susceptibility to other diseases
causes: Fungal infection by Cercospora zeae-maydis
Favors warm temperatures (77-86Â°F) and high humidity
Spreads rapidly in fields with high plant densities and poor air circulation
treatments: Plant maize varieties with genetic resistance to gray leaf spot
Rotate maize crops with non-host crops
Apply fungicides preventively, starting at early vegetative growth stages
prevention: Plant resistant maize varieties
Avoid planting maize in fields with a history of gray leaf spot
Practice crop rotation
Maintain good plant nutrition and irrigation practices
Use cultural practices such as wide row spacing and appropriate plant density to improve air circulation

Remove and destroy infected trees and plant new, disease-free trees

Practice good orchard sanitation, including removing infected plant debris
Use certified disease-free budwood for propagation
